Letter from Chief Executive
Dear Patient,
Important information about your treatment with us

There is some important information below about your treatment – which we aim to start within 18 weeks of your Primary care professional referring you – but first I would like to say thank you for choosing our Trust for your treatment. We hope your experience will show you made the right choice.
We will start your first treatment within 18 weeks

We aim to start your first treatment within, at the longest, 18 weeks from when your GP referred you to us. This means that if you need an operation, you will be admitted to hospital within a maximum of 18 weeks or, if your treatment can be given in an outpatient clinic, it will be started within that time. (Of course if your consultant decides that your treatment is needed urgently, it will be started much more quickly).
But we can only keep this promise with your help - you must make yourself available and attend appointments

During the time leading up to your treatment, it is vital that you are available for appointments, tests and treatment. Wherever possible, we will give you the opportunity to agree the date and time of your visits to make it easier for you to attend. However, if you are unable to attend an agreed appointment or come for your treatment, then please tell us straightaway so that we can offer that appointment to another patient. Your appointment letter explains how to contact us to do this.

If you do not attend for your first appointment, you may be referred by us back to the care of your GP. In these circumstances, we would then be happy to accept a new referral from your GP, if you and your GP agree that treatment is needed at some point in the future.
If you need an operation, you must be fit and well enough to undergo that operation within 18 weeks of referral.

If you may need an operation, your GP is likely to have already assessed your general fitness. If you are not fit enough to undergo surgery you may be returned to the care of your GP, until you meet the criteria to proceed.
We will try and avoid postponing your appointment wherever possible

There are occasions when we may have to cancel an appointment or your treatment, due to unforeseen circumstances. We try to avoid this at all times if possible, but if this happens we will contact you promptly to agree an alternative date.
The next steps in your care

We encourage patients to be involved in their care. Please ask our staff about the next steps towards your first treatment when you come for appointments or tests. We also welcome any comments or suggestions you have about our services, as feedback from you helps us to improve our services for everyone.
Finally, I welcome you to the hospital and hope that your experience of our services is as pleasant as possible.
Clare Panniker Chief Executive
Introduction

The best interests of the patient are foremost and the Trust intends to ensure efficient and equitable handling of referrals in line with waiting time standards and the NHS Constitution. The Constitution sets out your rights as an NHS patient. These rights cover how patients access health services, the quality of care you will receive, the treatments and programmes available to you, confidentiality, information and your right to complain if things go wrong. The constitution can be found by going to https://www.england.NHS.uk/2013/03/26/NHS-constitution.
Individual Patient Rights
The NHS Constitution clearly sets out a series of pledges and rights stating what patients, the public and staff can expect from the NHS. A patient has the right to the following:
The choice of hospital and consultant team (where available);
To commence their treatment for routine conditions following a referral into a consultant led service, within a maximum waiting time of 18 weeks to treatment;
To be seen by a cancer specialist within a maximum of two weeks from a GP referral for urgent referrals where cancer is suspected.
The NHS has to take all reasonable steps to offer a range of alternatives if this is not possible.
The right to be seen within the maximum waiting times does not apply if:
The patient chooses to wait longer;
Delaying the start of the treatment is in the best clinical interests of the patient (note that in both of these scenarios the patient's RTT clock continues to tick);
It is clinically appropriate for the patient's condition to be actively monitored in secondary care without clinical intervention or diagnostic procedure.
This policy has been produced in collaboration with the local CCGs to reflect local and national standards.

The policy covers the processes for booking, notice requirements, patient choice and waiting list management for all stages of a referral to treatment pathway. Giving patients more choice about how, when and where they receive treatment is one that requires us to offer a more responsive service to our patients needs through quality assurance. The length of time a patient waits for hospital treatment is an important quality issue and is a visibly and public indicator of the efficiency of the hospital services provided by the Trust.

This policy provides the basis for giving patients equitable access to health care, whilst applying agreed rules and conditions that will help facilitate the delivery of National targets and local contractual requirements. All targets defined within this policy are in line with National standards. The Trust will ensure that the management of patient access to services is transparent, fair and equitable and managed according to clinical priority. The policy will be applied consistently and without exception across the Trust to ensure equity amongst its patients whilst taking account of their clinical need.

The safety of vulnerable patients (Children and vulnerable adults, including those in prison) is paramount. In all cases clinical review should be undertaken before any removal from the waiting list (for a reason other than treatment). The clinician should always be made aware if the patient is a child or a vulnerable adult to be able to fully assess the best interests of the patient.

This policy applies to all administration and clinical prioritisation processes relating to patient access, including outpatient, inpatient, day case, therapies and diagnostic services. Treating patients, delivering a high quality and efficient service, as well as ensuring prompt communication with patients are core responsibilities of the hospital and the wider local health community.

This policy should be adhered to by all staff within the Trust who are responsible for referring patients, managing referrals, adding to and maintaining waiting lists for the purpose of progressing a patient through their treatment pathway.
Purpose

The purpose of this policy is to outline the Trust and Commissioner requirements and operating standards for managing patient access to secondary care services for patients from referral to treatment, and discharge to primary care.
The policy will:-
Establish a clear and consistent approach for patient access by defining the means by which patients may be referred to Trust services;
Describe how the Trust will manage access to its services and ensure that the pathway to treatment is fair for all and is compliant with the 18-week Referral to Treatment (RTT) rules;

Ensure that patients receive treatment according to their clinical priority; both suspected cancer patients and routine patients with the same clinical priority are treated in chronological order, thereby minimising the time a patient spends on the waiting list and improving the quality of the patient experience;
Support the reduction in waiting times, reduction in cancelled operations and the achievement of relevant waiting time targets;
Improve the patient experience by reducing DNA's (Did not attend) and cancellations;
Provide a framework by which administration of waiting lists and bookings will be managed;
Ensure that all the information relating to the number of patients waiting, seen and treated is accurate and recorded on ESR (Patient Administration System).
The advice given in the policy is, at all times, consistent with the national 18 Week rules;
Provide a framework by which administration of waiting lists and bookings will be managed.
Scope

This policy only applies to the management of elective episodes of care. For the management of Cancer pathways and access standards please refer to the Cancer Access Policy CM93 (available on the intranet).
All patients (except those on a cancer pathway) must be seen, diagnosed and treated within 18 weeks from Referral to Treatment (RTT).

Wherever possible for patients on an 18 week pathway, the principles of partial and full booking will be applied and patients will be encouraged to agree their appointment and admission dates and times in advance of their booking arrangements. The Trust recognises that recommendations for good practice specify the notice period to patients for these arrangements should where possible be a minimum of 3 weeks with two dates offered.

The Trust will therefore expect that referring clinicians will have alerted their patients to the appropriate pathway rules before the referral is made. They will further highlight to their patients the importance of them being available for any such appointments, tests and admissions that may be required along the pathway. Full booking applies to any new patients contacted and booked within 48 hours of their referral into the Trust and also applies to rapid access patients. It also applies to any patient who agrees the booking of their follow-up appointment when they leave the department after their clinic appointment.
Wider and more detailed information on procedures is available through a range of Patient Information Leaflets that are produced by the Trust for the patient.
The following national operating standards apply to all patients:
92% of open pathways will be under 18 weeks (this has become the sole measure of elective performance nationally);
There is no provision to pause or suspend an RTT waiting list clock under any circumstances.
No patient will wait any longer than 6 weeks for a diagnostic test or procedure from the date the decision is made.

data.text: Exclusions from 18 weeks
The following activity is excluded from the 18 week RTT standard:
Emergency admissions;
Obstetric patients;
Elective patients waiting for planned (Surveillance/Check) procedures;
Patients receiving on-going care for a condition where the first definitive treatment for that condition has already occurred;
Patients whose 18 week clock has stopped for active monitoring, and has not yet restarted, even though they may still be followed up by their consultant;
Referrals into a non-consultant-led service.
Roles and responsibilities
Access Board monitors RTT performance and adherence to the rules set out in this policy.
Specialty Operational Performance Reviews monitor compliance with RTT standards.
Activity and Performance meetings monitor RTT performance with specialties weekly.

Chief Executive is ultimately accountable for ensuring that effective processes are in place to manage patient care and treatment that meet National and local guidelines, and the NHS Constitution, and for achieving these standards.

Managing Directors are the individual Trusts Accountable Officers who have overall responsibility for ensuring that each site provides appropriate and timely access to services for its patients as set out in the NHS Plan, NHS Constitution and Operating Framework.
Directors of Operations – have strategic responsibility for the implementation of the Patient Access Policy, monitoring compliance and reporting performance to the Trust Board.

Medical Directors and the Clinical Directors are responsible for ensuring this policy is implemented and adhered to in all the services that they are responsible for, and that relevant staff are properly trained and monitored on compliance.
Directors of Nursing are the Trust's Caldicott Guardians and are responsible for the information Governance aspects of this policy.

Assistant Director of IT is responsible for the management of the EPR (Medway and Lorenzo) systems on which all waiting lists and appointment details are held, and the EMR systems which hold the patient clinical record electronically.

Information teams is responsible for the reporting of information to the Directors of Operations, including the provision of weekly PTLs and other reports as agreed with the RTT meeting core group, and recording the submission of central returns.

General Managers, Service Unit Managers and the Manager for Patient Access are responsible for the day-to-day management of the admitted and non- admitted waiting lists supported by Patient Pathway Staff and the 18 week Compliance Teams. All managers must ensure that staff have undertaken the relevant RTT training available to them. They are also accountable for compliance with this policy within their clinical directorates and the delivery of activity to meet the National and locally agreed standards.
All Staff involved in the Administration of Patient Appointments – are responsible for ensuring they are familiar with and follow the Trust's policy and procedures relating to patient access.
Consultants are individually responsible for ensuring that:
All referrals made using ERS are reviewed by the clinician or nominated member of staff within three working days of receipt of referral;
All referrals made using ERS are reviewed by the clinician or nominated member of staff within three working days of receipt of referral.
Referrals which are not reviewed within this agreed timeframe will be automatically accepted by the trust and the clinician will be expected to see the patient as booked.
Referrals returned to the originating referrer must be completed within three working days.

All Advice and Guidance requests submitted by GPs on ERS will be responded to by the requested consultant or designated deputy within two working days. Compliance with this is monitored as part of the National and Local contract performance indicators.
Clinic outcome forms are completed after consultations, to ensure accurate recording of the patient's pathway and RTT status.
All clinic letters are copied to the patient as well as GP's.

Patient care and treatment is achieved within the timescales laid down in the national, local and NHS constitution targets and standards. This will be achieved by working with the General Manager and clinical colleagues.
Potential or actual breaches of targets are alerted to the General Manager weekly.
Optimal medical staff management is achieved to ensure that scheduled outpatient clinics, patient treatment and operating theatre sessions are held and to avoid the need for patient cancellations.
Waiting lists are managed and that patient admissions / treatments are in line with clinical priority and order of inclusion onto the waiting list.
Patient cancellations are prevented and that those admissions which are cancelled for non-clinical reasons are rescheduled in line with timescales set out in this policy.

Accurate waiting time information is communicated to patients, their families and carers. They will also be responsible for dealing with any queries, problems or complaints relating to waiting times in line with trust policy.
Compliance with the commissioners' policies of Consultant to Consultant referrals and Service Restriction Policy is adhered to.
Patients DNAs are recorded in the patient record.
Patients who DNA an appointment are either contacted to arrange a further appointment or discharged to the care of their GP.
Waiting lists are monitored, and that data quality reports relating to these are
reviewed.
GP Responsibilities:
GPs must refer according to locally agreed protocols and best practice, using the Electronic Referrals System;
GPs will refer to the Suspected Cancer Guidelines when referring patients under the 2ww protocol for cancer;
When using ERS, the GP must upload the referral letter to the system within 3 days of referral;
GPs should ensure that patients are informed of the  week National Standard and their right to treatment within  weeks under the NHS Constitution;

GPs must include the most up to date patient contact details and demographic information, including mobile telephone numbers (where the patient has a mobile phone and is willing to supply this number) with every referral as well as results of relevant tests and details of current treatments and medication.

If the patient has any special needs, or is a vulnerable child or adult, or needs an interpreter to be present at the first appointment, the GP must make the Trust aware of this in their referral letter.
Patient Responsibilities:
Patients must attend appointments that they have previously agreed, or contact the Trust as soon as they are aware that they cannot attend.
Patients must provide accurate information about their health known conditions and general health status.
Patients are to be involved in the management and planning of their care
Patients should inform their GP practice of any change of address or contact numbers
Commissioners Responsibilities:

Commissioners will work with GPs to ensure that agreed referral protocols are adhered to, and that funding requests for restricted treatment, submitted by The Trust are assessed appropriately, within the agreed turnaround time of three working days;
Commissioners will work with GPs to ensure this is the only method of referral;
Commissioners will manage local service provision and ensure that services
are provided within a maximum of 18 weeks;
Commissioners will offer suitable alternative providers where capacity is unsufficient to meet 18 week standard.
Entitlement to NHS treatment

The Trust has a legal obligation to identify patients who are not eligible for free NHS treatment. The NHS provides healthcare for people who live in the UK. People who do not normally live in this country are not automatically entitled to use the NHS free of charge – regardless of their nationality or whether they hold a British ESRsport or have lived and paid National Insurance contributions and taxes in this country in the ESRt. An NHS card or number does not give automatic entitlement to free NHS treatment.

NHS Entitlement is based upon UK residency – and not on nationality. If the patient has been living outside the UK for more than three months in the last year –they may not  automatically qualify and may be required to pay for treatment and will need to have their entitlement investigated even if a UK citizen. The Trust has a responsibility to ensure that any patient given treatment under the NHS is entitled to receive that treatment free of charge; in turn the patient has a duty to provide evidence, when asked, to confirm that entitlement.

Patients resident in Scotland & Wales are entitled to receive emergency treatment at the Trust when required, however prior approval for all elective treatments, including Outpatient appointments, must be obtained (from the relevant Health Board) before booking an appointment or receiving treatment. This can be done via:-
Mid Essex – Interprovider office;
Southend – Private and Overseas office; Basildon -servicedevelopment@btuh.nhs.uk.

ED treatment is free to all until the patient is admitted as an inpatient or attends an outpatient appointment. For this further treatment, all overseas patients need to provide a copy of their ESRsport, visa (if applicable) and proof of address.

Patients resident in the European Union must supply their EHIC card or a PRC certificate. If an EHIC card is not supplied the patient will be charged for their treatment as a private patient. Patients from non-EU countries will be charged for this treatment as private patients; if they have health insurance they will be required to show their health insurance documentation.
NHS Trusts legal obligations
All NHS Trusts have a legal obligation to:
Ensure that patients who are not ordinarily resident in the UK are identified;
Assess liability for charges in accordance with Department of Health Overseas Visitors Regulations;
Charge those liable to pay in accordance with Department of Health Overseas
Visitors Regulations.
The Human Rights Act 1998

The Human Rights Act prohibits discrimination against a person on any ground such as race, colour, language or religion. The way to avoid accusations of discrimination is to ensure that everybody is treated the same way.
Staff as Patients

This policy applies to staff as patients. All staff will require a GP letter of referral to receive a consultant appointment, be registered on EPR and eligible for NHS treatment. The consultation will take place in an Outpatient clinic. There should be no fast-tracking process for staff although it is recognised that in some occasions where staff employed by MSE are off work on long term sick leave awaiting a treatment or procedure, it may be advantageous to the tax payer and the greater good if the staff member is seen quicker so they can return to work.
Overseas Visitors
An overseas visitor is defined as: - a person who is not ordinarily resident in the UK. Residency is defined as – Living lawfully in the UK.

Treatment is free at point of contact for all patients in an A&E department. However, once a patient is referred to an outpatient clinic (or added to an elective waiting list) or admitted as an emergency to a ward, this treatment is no longer free for an overseas visitor unless evidence can be shown that they have a reciprocal agreement entitling them to free healthcare.

All patients ‘without exception' should be asked ‘Have you lived in the UK for the ESRt 12 months' and asked to provide evidence of residency in the UK to prove entitlement to free NHS treatment within secondary care for example; a contract of employment if employed; utility bill; tenancy agreement or bank statement along with their ESRsport or identification card for EU Citizens.

The above question must be asked of all patients at each point of contact within the Trust. This is a legal responsibility of the Trust and is therefore the responsibility of all who have first line contact with patients, be it in outpatients or on a ward.

Where a patient has not lived in the UK for the ESRt 12 months or cannot provide evidence of residency, the Private Patient and Overseas Patient Office (PPOP) must be contacted to interview the patient before treatment commences (unless this treatment is clinically urgent).
Ministry Of Defence Patients

In line with the Armed Forces Covenant published in 2015, all veterans and war pensioners should receive priority access to NHS care for any condition related to their services. The GP referral must clearly outline the condition and its relation to military service. In line with clinical policy, patients with more urgent clinical needs will continue to receive priority.
HMP Prison Patients (HMP)

Referral for HMP patients are processed via the same means as any other manual referral and all RTT rules apply. However, the Healthcare Department is contacted by telephone and the first convenient appointment arranged in order to minimise the risk of cancellations.
Transfer of Private Patients
Patients Transferring from Private to NHS

Patients can choose to convert between an NHS and private status at any point during their pathway without prejudice. Patients wishing to transfer from the private service to the NHS must be returned to their GP to be offered choice for onward referral to an NHS provider. A new clock start will be generated for this referral reflecting a zero week wait.
No patient should be referred direct to the Trust from the independent service. If patients require an Outpatient appointment they should be referred as a new patient via their GP.

Patients who are referred via their GPs from an independent service can, if the receiving consultant decides, be added directly to the NHS waiting list on the referral received date (this will be the RTT clock start date). They do not necessarily need an NHS outpatient appointment prior to addition.

NB: patients who start an 18w clock in NHS outpatients, who choose to pay for their procedure in the independent sector and then choose to return to the NHS for follow up care, must be re-referred by their GP post-op and cannot be referred directly from the independent sector to the Trust
Patients Transferring from NHS to Private
NHS patients already on a waiting list opting to have a private procedure must be removed from the NHS waiting list and referred back to their GP; this will stop the RTT clock.
Outsourcing of Patient Care from NHS to the Private sector

There are occasions when the Trust may choose to send patients to the independent sector for some of their RTT pathway, for example an open MRI or surgical procedure. Where the Trust is commissioning the service, the patient remains on their 18w clock and the same rules apply.
Procedures which require funding from CCGs
Prior Approval

There are a number of procedures deemed low priority or low clinical effectiveness. Any patient requiring one of these procedures, tests or interventions must have confirmed funding (on an individual basis) from the CCG prior to booking the appointment. Lists of these procedures can be obtained via the Trust intranet or contract management team or directly from the CCG's websites (Value Based Commissioning Policy June 2018).
Any requests for funding must be actioned and logged through the General Manager of the service. The following timescales, requirements and processes apply. See link on page  of document.

Funding requests (the clinic letter and a copy of the waiting list form) must be sent to the CCG within 5 working days of the clinic date to avoid any unnecessary waiting for the patients. The patients will be informed that funding has been requested and that they are not currently on a waiting list.
The Outpatient appointment outcome must be entered as “awaiting funding approval”.
The 18 Week Pathway will continue whilst funding is sought.
The date the request for funding is made will be logged on the ESR.
When funding is approved the patient will be placed on the waiting list and pre- assessment arranged if required.
When funding is refused the patient will be discharged. It is CCG's responsibility to inform the patient if a funding request has been refused.
A reminder email will be sent to the CCG if, by the fifth day, no response has been received.
Where no response is received, the patient will be placed on the waiting list.
Should the CCG's request additional information from the GP - the patient and the Consultant will be kept updated.
Individual Funding Requests

Patients have the opportunity to make specific funding requests via the Individual Funding Request team at the CCG. Requests may include conditions for which the CCGs do not have an agreed policy, including patients with rare conditions and whose proposed treatment is outside agreed service agreements. In instances in which eligibility is unclear, the final decision is made through an application to the Individual Funding Requests team by contacting them at: MECCG.IFR@nhs.net. Documents related to requests and Value Basded Commissioning policies can be accessed via the following link:-
https://midessexccg.nhs.uk/about-us/the-library/service-restriction-policies
Principles
What is the 18 RTT Week Patient Pathway?

Since the end of December 2008 no one should wait more than 18 weeks (127 days) from referral to the start of hospital treatment. This includes all the stages that lead up to treatment, including outpatient consultations, diagnostic tests and procedures.

The 18 Week Patient Pathway does not replace other waiting times, targets or standards where these are shorter than 18 weeks (127 days). This includes waiting times for cancer patients and waiting times for Rapid Access Chest Pain Clinics.
Key Elements of RTT

All patients will be managed according to their clinical urgency, and within the 18 Week Referral to Treatment (RTT) standard. Performance will be judged against the following waiting time standards:
Nationally monitored and reported Incomplete operational standard of 92%
– the percentage of incomplete pathways within 18 weeks should equal or exceed 92%;
Locally monitored Admitted operational standard of 90% – the percentage of admitted pathways (on an adjusted basis) within 18 weeks should equal or exceed 90%);
Locally monitored Non-admitted operational standard of 95% – the percentage of non-admitted pathways within 18 weeks should equal or exceed
13.3.2 The referral to treatment (RTT) operational standards should be achieved in each specialty and this will be monitored monthly.
13.3.3 Performance will also be assessed alongside other data:
An admitted pathway means that the patient requires admission to hospital, as either a day case or an inpatient, to receive their first definitive treatment;
A  non-admitted  pathway means that the patient does not require admission to hospital to receive their first definitive treatment, i.e. that treatment is given or prescribed in outpatients;
Patients are managed and measured on a non-admitted pathway until
the point at which they require admission for treatment as either a day
case or inpatient, at which point they are included in the admitted target;

The 18 week clock starts on the date that a referral is received by the Trust; this is the start of an 18 week clock for that patient. That clock then continues to tick until either the first definitive treatment is given, or
another event occurs which can stop the clock;
An 18 week clock can also start at another healthcare provider and then the patient can be transferred to the Trust, where the clock continues to tick from the original start date;

The following can all start 18 week clocks for patients: GPs; Optometrists; Orthoptists; GUM services; A&E; Walk in Centre, National Screening Programmes; Prison Health Services; and specialist nurses and AHPs who have primary care authorisation to refer directly to consultants;

The only route of Referrals from GPs is via ERS. Bookings made via this means will be received on the basis that the clinical letter will be attached to the referral via the Electronic Referral Service (ERS)

For patients who are referred using ERS, the 18 week clock starts on the date on which the patient activates their referral to convert their Unique Booking Reference Number (UBRN) into an appointment. For patients not referred using ERS, the  week clock starts on the date their referral is received by the Trust;

Where a referral goes initially to a Referral Management Service (RMS) i.e. MSK the  week clock starts on the date on which the RMS receives the referral. An Inter-provider transfer minimum data set must accompany the referral if the patient is then referred into Consultant –led services in secondary care;

Each step along the patient's pathway (outpatient appointment diagnostic appointment excluding radiology, pre-assessment, admission, discharge, any decision by the patient or clinician to delay further treatment at any stage) must be correctly recorded in Electronic Patient Record (EPR);

Patients may have more than one  week RTT waiting time ticking simultaneously if they have been referred to and are under the care of more than one clinician at any point in time. Each 18 week pathway has to be measured and monitored separately and will have a unique pathway ID number in EPR.

13.3.4 There are a number of different activities which may occur during a patient's treatment pathway, and each is defined according to whether they start, stop or continue an 18 week RTT waiting time. Understanding these elements of 18 week pathways is one of the most complicated elements of the 18 week standard. A brief  description of each of these possible stages along the treatment pathway is therefore given in section 2.
Exclusions from 18 Weeks
The following activity is excluded from the 18 week RTT standard:
Emergency admissions;
Obstetric patients;
Elective patients waiting for planned (Surveillance/Check) procedures;
Patients receiving on-going care for a condition where the first definitive treatment for that condition has already occurred;
Patients whose 18 week clock has stopped for active monitoring, and has not yet restarted, even though they may still be followed up by their consultant;
Referrals into a non-consultant-led service;
Referrals to Mental Health services.
RTT Pathway
Clock Starts
A clock start is when a referral to a consultant led service is received for diagnosis
and treatment of a patient's condition. The most common clock starts are:-
Referral received from Primary Care
For most patients, the clock will begin when the GP refers the patient to a consultant, or consultant grouping, in secondary care. The date that the secondary
care provider receives the patient's referral is the date the clock starts. Note that this should only be used for the very first receipt of the referral.

14.2.1 For referrals made through ERS, the clock starts on the date on which the patient makes the appointment. When a patient is referred to a hospital by their GP, they receive a Unique Booking Reference Number (UBRN). The GP surgery may assist the patient with selecting an appointment date and time using the unique URBN or instruct the patient to contact the ERS appointment line either by phone or by logging into the ERS website. The RTT clock starts at the point the appointment is made.
14.2.2 Opticians and Dentists do not have access to ERS and therefore electronic referrals will be sent directly to the relevant booking service within secondary care provider.
14.2.3 TheWeek Patient Pathway clock starts with referrals from Primary Care to the following services:
Medical or surgical consultant-led services - irrespective of setting;
Cancer services, for which a 62 day cancer target clock also starts if a 2 week wait (2ww) referral has been used;

Diagnostic services provided the patient will be assessed and, if appropriate, treated by a medical or surgical consultant-led service before responsibility is transferred back to the referring health professional;
Referral Management Services which cover arrangements known as clinical advisory centres, integrated clinical assessment and treatment services, interface services etc;
Practitioners with special interests if they are part of a referral management arrangement as defined;
Where a patient has been seen privately and then is referred by the GP to an NHS service after being offered choice (see Section 11).
Consultant  to  consultant  referral  for  a  condition  unrelated  to the  original referring condition
This is where a consultant sees a patient in clinic having been referred for condition A and then, following a consultation, refers on to another consultant

(within the Trust) for a different condition (condition B). This consultant referral starts a new, second 18 week clock for condition B. The original 18 week clock which was started by the referral for condition A continues to tick. As a patient's care is best coordinated by their GP, consultant to consultant referrals should only occur in urgent cases. If the referral is not urgent, the patient should be returned to their GP for further management/referrals.
14.3.1    Consultant (or consultant-led service) referrals can also start the clock, specifically if:
Separate conditions or complications developed with pregnancy, or if a new- born baby is suspected of having a condition requiring medical or surgical consultant-led treatment;
New conditions are identified as a result of a genetic test;
A patient on a programme of long-term care, non-consultant led, has a decision to treat made (at follow-up outpatients) that needs to be medical or surgical consultant-led;
The patient is put on the waiting list for a therapeutic procedure after active monitoring (watchful waiting).
End of Active Monitoring
If, after a period of active monitoring, the patient or the Care Professional then decides that treatment is now appropriate, a new 18 week clock starts. This new

clock starts at 0 weeks; it does not restart at the point at which the previous clock was stopped. There is then a new 18 week period in which the patient must receive their first definitive treatment.
14.4.1  Please note that referrals from Primary Care to the following services will not start an RTT clock:-

Therapy, healthcare science or mental health services that are not medical or surgical consultant-led (including multi-disciplinary teams and community teams run by mental health trusts) irrespective of setting;
Diagnostic services if the referral is not part of a straight –to-test arrangement;
Primary dental services provided by dental students in hospital settings.
On-Going Clocks
A patient has an on-going clock if they have had a clock start but have not yet had either their first definitive treatment, or decision not to treat. This might be
because they have not yet had a follow up appointment, a diagnostic test/image or they have been added to a patient to a waiting list for admission.
Transfer to another Healthcare Provider
If a patient is referred from one provider to another as part of their RTT period, their 18 week clock should keep ticking. When transferring patients on an

RTT pathway to another provide outside of the Trust, an Inter-Provider Transfer Minimum Data Set (IPTMDS) must be completed which includes data around the patient and their 18w clock, as part of the referral. The 18 week compliance team must be informed if a patient is being transferred to an external provider so that the pathway can be amended to reflect this.
If a patient is referred to another Trust for opinion or review, their RTT status remains ongoing as it is likely that the patient will return for further
management.
If a patient is referred to another provider for treatment, their RTT status will be changed to ongoing referral to external provider. Although the clock
keeps ticking, it is the receiving provider who will stop the patient's clock when treatment is given.
Transfer from another Healthcare Provider
Other organisations may transfer their patients already on an 18w clock direct to the Trust for tertiary/specialist care. On receipt of the referral the clock
continues to tick. The referral must be accompanied by an Inter-Provider Transfer Minimum Data set (IPTMDS) which includes data around the patient and their 18w clock.
Clock Stops
A clock stop is when a clinical decision is made that treatment is not required or when first definitive treatment begins or when a patient declines treatment. First

definitive treatment can be described as the start of the first treatment that is intended to manage a person's disease, condition or injury. This can occur in either an Outpatient or Inpatient setting.
First Definitive Treatment Given
This is the point at which the patient receives their first definitive treatment. A patient's First Definitive Treatment is an intervention intended to manage a patient's
disease, condition or injury and avoid further intervention. This stops the current 18 week clock previously started.
Start of a period of active monitoring/watchful waiting
The concept of active monitoring (watchful waiting) stops the clock and caters for periods of care without new clinical intervention eg three monthly routine check- ups for diabetic patients.
Where it is clinically appropriate to monitor the patient in secondary care without clinical intervention or further diagnostic procedures, or where a patient

wishes to continue to be reviewed as an outpatient, or have an open appointment, without progressing to more invasive treatment. Active monitoring (watchful waiting) can be initiated by either the patient or the clinician. The start of a period of active monitoring stops the RTT waiting time.
A new RTT clock would start when a decision to treat is made following a period of Active Monitoring
Patient does not attend (DNAs) their first care activity following referral
When a patient fails to attend the first activity (appointment or diagnostic test) in their pathway, their clock will be stopped and they will be returned to the care of
the GP providing that:
The appointment was clearly communicated;
Discharging the patient is carried out in line with the Trust's DNA policy;
The patient is not a vulnerable patient;
The patient has not been referred on a 2ww pathway;
The decision to discharge a patient must be made by the appropriate clinician and must be communicated to the patient and GP in writing.
If the decision is made to reappoint a first care activity after a first DNA, their original 18 week clock is nullified and a new one restarted from the date
they are contacted to re-book a new appointment.

For patients who DNA and are discharged back to their GP, should the GP wish the patient to receive treatment, they can re-refer them – a new 18w clock would start on receipt of the re-referral at the Trust.
Patient DNAs subsequent activity on pathway prior to first treatment
When a patient DNAs a subsequent appointment this will not stop the RTT clock. However if a patient DNAs two appointments, for example diagnostic test

or image, pre-assessment appointment or TCI for elective admission; Consultants must review the patient's notes before deciding if the patient should be reappointed or discharged to the care of the GP. Special consideration must be given to children and vulnerable patients.
The decision to discharge a patient must be made by the appropriate clinician and must be communicated to the patient and GP in writing.
If the patient is re-appointed, as this is not a first care activity, the patient's 18w clock would continue to tick. Should the GP wish the patient to receive
treatment after discharge, then they can re-refer them – a new 18w clock would start on receipt of the re-referral at the Trust.
Patient cancels care activity prior to treatment for the second time
When a patient cancels the same care activity for the second occasion on their pathway (e.g. patient cancels an outpatient appointment for the second time),
the patients status must be reviewed by the Consutant for either discharge or re- appointment.
The decision to discharge a patient must be made by the appropriate clinician and must be communicated to the patient and GP in writing.
Should the patient wish to receive treatment, then they can be re-referred by their GP – a new clock would start on receipt of the re- referral at the Trust.
Decision not to treat/no treatment required
When the clinician determines that treatment is not required or a decision that no treatment is to occur; the patient's clock is stopped. The patient can either

be returned to the care of the GP or remain under the care of the Consultant as required.  A  decision  not  to  treat/no  treatment  required  may  occur  outside  a clinical consultation, for example if a patient is discharged on the basis of a test result which is communicated to the patient and their GP by letter. This can occur at any stage of the patient's pathway and will stop the clock on the date of the phone call or letter.
Patient declines offered treatment
Patients may choose not to proceed with the treatment offered and therefore their clock is stopped on the date they inform the Trust.
Open Appointments
When a patient has been reviewed by the Consultant and a decision has been made that no further appointments are required the patient will either be:
Discharged or
Discharged and offered the opportunity to be seen again within six months if their condition changes, this is referred to as an open appointment. This will not be applicable to all patients.

14.16.1 For the cohort of patients where an open appointment has been offered the RTT clock will be stopped (active monitoring stopped) and a note recorded on EPR as ‘6 months open appointment'. A letter must be sent to the patient outlining this agreement.
14.16.2 If a patient contacts the Trust within the 6 month period the pathway can be reactivated and active monitoring re-instated.
14.16.3 If patient contacts the Trust after the 6 month time period they should be advised to contact their GP for review.
Acute Therapy Services
Acute therapy services consist of physiotherapy, dietetics orthotics and surgical appliances. Referrals to these services can be:
Directly from GP where an RTT clock would not be applicable;

During an open RTT pathway where the intervention is intended as first definitive treatment (clock stop) or as an interim measure for symptom control before treatment (this will nbot be a clock stop).

15.1.2 There are recognised exceptions to this process (refer to Appendix 1).

Consultant Referrals to other Trusts

Referrals to other Trusts must only be made when directly related to the original referral reason. It must be made using the interprovider transfer form ensuring that all data (MDS) is completed. The process will be monitored through the central RTT Compliance team.
Consultant Referrals from other Trusts
Referrals may only be received from other Trusts if the following two fundamental pieces of information are submitted:
15.5.1 The referral to the Trust is directly relating to the reason for the original referral to the referring consultant.
15.5.2 Full set of demographic details, RTT clock start date and patient's current RTT status on the Minimum Data sent (MDS).

Consultant to Consultant Referrals within this Trust
It has been agreed with commissioners that consultant-to-consultant referrals
can occur in line with the existing agreed policy (C2C Protocol June 2018). Referrals may be submitted to the receiving consultant in an appropriate referral letter.
15.6.1  It must be made clear on the referral letter that this is a continuation of an existing RTT pathway and not for a newly identified condition unless the following have been identified:
The patient is under the age of 19 years;
For investigation, management or treatment of cancer, or suspected cancer, in line with criteria for referral (2 week waits);
Where symptoms or signs suggest a life threatening or urgent condition that requires the patient be seen in less than 2 weeks;
Where there exists suspected adult or child safeguarding concerns.

It would be safe to make a referral back to primary care or to a community service (where a community service exists that can provide an alternative to secondary care management).

15.7.1 A patient reveals symptoms unrelated to the referring condition or incidental findings which do not require urgent referral.
