Discharged to primary care or
Referred to the CATS (Clinical Assessment Triage Service) service, in line with the agreed pain pathway.
Inappropriate Referrals

When a consultant deems a referral to be clinically inappropriate, it must be sent back to the referring GP with an explanation why. The referral decision must be updated and discharged accordingly. Where a referral has been made and the special interest of the consultant does not match the needs of the patient, the consultant should re-direct the referral to the appropriate colleague in the same service or reject back to the GP to refer to the correct service.
Outpatient stages
Patients are administrated through the outpatient part of the RTT (Referral to Treatment) pathway in three main stages. They are Registration, Booking and Attendance.
Registration
All referral received via ERS will automatically be registered within the EPR.
All non ERS referrals will be checked against the Trust's EPR. If the patient is already registered the details must be checked and amended accordingly.
Full details will be entered to allocate a hospital number if the patient is not registered at the Trust.
Referrals with no NHS number should be checked on the National Summary Care Record by department staff. The GP and/or Data Quality Team should be contacted for clarity on any details.
Patients referred via E-referral where an NHS number cannot be found will be allocated a “Y” number on the EPR registration.
The original copy of the referral letter will be held on the patient's electronic medical record for ease of reference.
Non ERS referrals will be scanned and forwarded to the relevant Specialty for Consultant grading. This is to be actioned within 5 days on receipt of the referral.
Booking
18 week RTT Booking Timescales

All non ERS referrals will be received into Outpatient Booking Team to establish whether there is an RTT clock start or not and, where necessary, establish the clock start date and prevent duplicate referrals.
19.1.1 For BTUH referrals are scanned into the EPR, an appointment slot is allocate and sent to the patient. No triage of referrals is undertaken.

19.1.2 For SUH and MEHT the call centre team will scan the letter and send electronically to the relevant specialty for acceptance/clinical prioritisation within 2 working days from receipt. The referral is then returned electronically to the call centre for booking or held and booked within the specialty.

19.1.3 Communication with the patient will be initiated as soon as the clinician has indicated the relevant pathway. Where possible, patients should be offered the earliest available mutually convenient appointment date adhering to target timeframes, clinical priority and “in turn”. Relevant comments are to be recorded in the comments field on EPR.
19.1.4 Any patients that cannot be contacted on two separate occasions will be sent a  first available appointment and asked to ring in and confirm attendance where possible.
19.1.5 Following confirmation with the patient of their appointment this is then verified on the EPR.
19.1.6 When patients have been referred on to the outpatient waiting list they may not be expedited unless there is a late notice cancellation or consultant agrees to expedite.
Lack of Clinic Capacity
ASI lists are distributed from the Outpatient Booking Service as a minimum weekly
to all specialties for action.
19.2.1  Specialty staff will inform the Outpatient Booking Service where the additional clinic capacity will be provided to meet the ASI demand.
Private Patients
Private patients are recorded on EPR under the referral as PP for a Private patient, then the appointment type as P for a new appointment or OP for a review appointment.
19.3.1 Rules regarding the acceptance of Private Patients are described in section 11 above.

19.3.2 It is important to ensure that the parameters of equity are observed and patients who have transferred with an NHS pathway in the private sector are not disadvantaged and are allowed to enter the RTT at the appropriate part of the pathway, this will be part of the MDS sent to the Trust.
Compliance with procedures

All staff involved in the booking of appointments must follow the processes of the Trust to ensure compliance with the RTT rules and enable the Trust to achieve its clinical obligation to meet the appropriate time scales.
First appointment internal target
The key outpatient internal operating target is that no patient will wait for more than 8 weeks from referral for their first outpatient appointment.
The General Principles for Outpatients
Patients are seen in the order of clinical priority and date of referral.
19.6.1 Patients have a single point of contact at the Trust – call centre for outpatients and the POD (BTUH), Specialty Service Manager (SUH), Patient Access Team (MEHT) for inpatients and day cases.

19.6.2 Where patients have been seen and discharged with the option that they may have a follow up appointment  within  months from the date of discharge, it is the patient's responsibility to contact the hospital if they wish to be seen providing it is within 6 months.
19.6.3 If the 6 month period has elapsed it is the patient's responsibility to contact the GP
to make a new referral.

19.6.4 Staff must abide by the parameters of the clinic structure (template) available. Conversion of new and follow up slots to ensure full utilisation is maintained can only be done in conjunction with the outpatient booking teams and the consultants.
19.6.5 Cancelled slots must be given to the next longest waiting patient.
19.6.6 The Trust will operate a waiting list system based on taking patients in turn except for emergencies and cancer patients. .

19.6.7 When making the appointment, the booking on EPR must be linked to the appropriate referral which has already been logged. Staff must ensure that duplicate referrals are not created as this will cause double counting and miscalculation of a patient's waiting time.

19.6.8 The patient will be sent a confirmation letter or contacted by telephone regarding their booked appointment. The letter must be clear and informative and should include a point of contact to call if they have any queries or concerns. The letter should explain clearly the consequences should the patient cancel or fail to attend at the designated time.
19.6.9 Where cancellations are initiated by the Trust, patients should be rebooked as close to their original appointment as possible.
19.6.10 The policy of the Trust is that 6 weeks' notice of clinic cancellations must be given. General Managers and Clinical Leads must give authorisation for cancellations of less than 6 weeks.
Clinic Management
Notice of appointment to Patients

Patients should be given choice in their appointment date and therefore full use of the available pathway time must be used. In accordance with the national guidance a ‘reasonable offer' of appointment involves giving a patient the offer of 2 dates with at least 3 weeks' notice of their appointment:
Urgent patients may be offered one reasonable notice date (the other offers may be under 3 weeks);
All dates offered are recorded on ESR;
Where a patient declines 2 reasonable offers, in agreement with clinician, the patient may be removed from the outpatient list and referred back to the GP
If an offer of appointment is made for less than 3 weeks and is accepted by the patient it will be treated as a reasonable offer.
Medical Staff Notice of Annual Leave and Study Leave

A minimum of 6 weeks' notice of annual leave, study leave, professional leave or ‘Consultant of the week' commitments must be given when a clinician requests a scheduled clinic to be cancelled or reduced. In all circumstances a Clinic Cancellation/Reduction form must be  completed and sent to the General Manager (and Clinical Lead) to be authorised.
20.2.1  Clinic cancelation form will not be accepted unless full patient level details are attached with rebook dates for each patient.
Clinic Cancellations/Reductions
Clinic cancellations should be initiated by the relevant specialty using the appropriate Clinic Cancellation electronic form.
20.3.1 Clinic cancelation form will not be accepted unless full patient level details are attached with rebook dates for each patient.
20.3.2 Where ad hoc slot reduction is requested by Clinicians for any reason the Clinic Cancellation/reduction form must be completed and agreed by the General Manager and Clinical Director
20.3.3 The necessary changes will be implemented within 2 working days of receipt of the authorisation.
Clinic cancellation request, less than 6 weeks
No clinics are to be cancelled at less than 6 weeks' notice without both the General Manager's and the Clinical Lead's approval.
20.4.1 At BTUH the Director of Operations and Medical Director are to be included where leave is requested with less that 6 weeks notice.

20.4.2 The default position will be that clinics are covered by another medical professional rather than cancelled. In exceptional circumstances where patients have to be cancelled at short notice, the clinician must be able to offer alternative dates to the patient without significantly lengthening the waiting time standard pertinent at that time. Evidence of discussions should be recorded on the clinic cancellation form.
20.4.3 It is only after these actions have been authorised that patients will be contacted.
Clinic reinstatement
Clinics can only be reinstated if:
4 weeks notice of the clinic date has been given;
Clinic staff are available;
A clinic room is available.
Clinic Template Management
Clinic templates are maintained by the EPR and Outpatient booking teams.
20.6.1 Amendments  to existing  templates should be given 6 weeks' notice  and  will be initiated on receipt of approval from the General Manager and Clinical Director.
20.6.2 The changes will be phased in over 6 weeks ahead to allow for patients to be rebooked.

20.6.3 New templates involving the creation of new capacity to book patients not previously assigned appointments will be initiated by the EPR/system mangers within 48 hours of receipt of approval. Does not require GM/CD approval.
20.6.4 Changes to Nurse Led clinics will be approved by the Head of Nursing/Matron for the service.
Follow up appointments
The Trust operates on the basis that:
Patients should not be recalled for follow-up appointments unless absolutely essential;
Follow up appointment booking may be as either partial booking (at SUH) or full booking;
Patients should leave clinic with a follow up appointment agreed for services operating a full booking system.
Partial Booking
The Trust operates a Partial Booking system for some services.
20.8.1 All appointments where the patient is to be seen in 6 weeks or under are booked at the reception desk when the patient leaves clinic.
20.8.2 The same applies for vulnerable patients and those where their medical condition requires a firm appointment or series of appointments to be booked

20.8.3 The only exception is where clinic capacity does not exist. A patient that remains undated beyond 6 weeks of the due by date is reviewed by the clinician to assess the clinical risk of delay. Patients must be added to the Partial Booking review list on the EPR.
20.8.4 Patients requiring appointments over 6 weeks ahead are added to a waiting list and an appointment 6 weeks' prior to their due date is arranged where capacity allows.
20.8.5 Patients will be sent a letter asking them to contact the Trust to agree a follow up appointment.

20.8.6 Where a patient does not respond to the invite letter or do not attend their follow up appointment, the clinician will review the notes in the clinic setting and decide if a further appointment should be booked.
20.8.7 However, if the review appointment is considered non-urgent, after clinical review, a further appointment may be offered.
20.8.9 Where the clinician decides that an urgent review is still required, a further
appointment will be offered.
20.8.10 This decision must be made immediately to ensure that the appropriate outcome is recorded.
Hospital Initiated Cancellations

The clock continues to tick if the Trust cancels a patient's outpatient appointment. For new referral appointments cancelled, the revised appointment must not breach the current waiting time standard.

20.9.1 Cancellation of a follow up appointment will result in rebooking and the new date must take account of the clinical prioritisation, whilst also avoiding the potential to breach the RTT standard.

20.9.2 Particular attention by specialty teams must be paid to appointments that may potentially be cancelled where ‘clock stopping' treatment was planned to be carried out in clinic. This would avoid potential breaches under these circumstances. For example treatment clinics, post diagnostic result clinics.
20.9.3 Wherever possible, patients who have been cancelled once should not be cancelled for a second time unless, as a result of clinical reprioritisation, there is no other option.

20.9.4 Clinicians will be informed of hospital initiated delays (where two concurrent cancellations have already been made and a third is attempted) to ensure that no harm is likely to result from the patient waiting longer for treatment (clinicians may indicate in advance, for each specialty or pathway, how long it is clinically safe for patients to delay their treatment before their case should be reviewed).
20.9.5 Where necessary, clinicians will review each and every patient's case on an individual basis to determine whether the delay is clinically acceptable.

20.9.6 The patient will be contacted by either the Outpatient booking team or Specialty team If an agreed appointment needs to be cancelled in less than 6 weeks' who will agree an alternative date and time.
Patient Initiated Cancellations
Where the patient gives any prior notice that they cannot attend their appointment (even if this is on the day of clinic), this should be recorded as a cancellation and not a DNA.
20.10.1 If a patient cancels an appointment for the first time, another appointment must be re-arranged if required. This appointment will be made for the next available date.

20.10.2 Patients can choose to postpone or amend their appointment or treatment if they wish, regardless of the resulting waiting time. However If the patient requests a cancellation of an appointment for a second time the Clinician will be informed of
the patient initiated delay to ensure that no harm is likely to result from the patient waiting longer for treatment
20.10.3 Where necessary, clinicians will review each and every patient's case on an individual basis to determine whether:
The requested delay is clinically acceptable;

The requested delay is clinically acceptable, but the clinician believes the delay will have a consequential impact (where the treatment may fundamentally change during the period of delay) on the patient's treatment. The patient should be contacted to review their options and either agree to attend as planned or be discharged to the care of their GP;
The patient's best clinical interest would be served by discharging them to the care of their GP;

Patients who cancel an ERS appointment but do not subsequently re-book will receive two reminder letters from ERS. If the patient has not rebooked 5 days after the second reminder has been sent, they will have their appointment request cancelled. Should the patient attempt to re-use the UBRN after that time, they will be advised to return to their GP or referrer;
If the patient is subsequently re-referred by the GP this will be logged as a new referral and will start a new  week RTT pathway;
Where a patient is subsequently re-referred this will constitute as a new clock start, and the patient will be classified as another new referral attendee.
Patient request for discharge from Service
When a patient no longer wishes to be seen, they may choose to cancel their

outpatient appointment and this will stop the RTT pathway. This will result in discharge back to the care of their GP. The RTT clock will be stopped as a consequence by the person receiving the notification from the patient.

20.11.1 It is imperative that EPR is updated immediately using the date that the patient contacted the Trust to cancel their appointment. A letter is sent to the GP to inform them that the patient has been discharged.
Patients who DNA clinic appointments

At the end of a clinic, all DNAs should be reviewed by the consultant or one of their clinical team to decide if the normal access policy steps should be followed for routine patients who DNA or if patients fall into the exceptions to the policy. See section 14.1 above.

20.12.1 Where the clinician, on review of the notes at the end of the clinic, decides that the patient clinically requires an appointment another will be offered to the patient. The RTT clock continues during this period, unless this was  a first outpatient attendance.

20.12.2 The RTT clock is nullified if this was a first outpatient appointment. The outpatient clock will restart from the date the Trust and patient agree on a new appointment date if a further appointment is offered.

20.12.3 Where the clinician, on review of the notes at the end of the clinic, decides that the patient does not clinically require the appointment, and reasonable notice was given, the patient will be discharged back to the GP and the clock stopped.

20.12.4 The only exception for the above is children under the age of 18 or people in care (Vulnerable Adults) or on a cancer pathway, another appointment will be offered. Subsequent DNA's will be discussed with the clinicians and safeguarding teams if appropriate.
20.12.5 The clinician must record the outcome before the clinic ends – either the patient is discharged or must be offered another appointment
20.12.6 This decision must be made immediately to ensure that the appropriate RTT outcome is recorded on ESR.
20.12.7 Where the patient is subsequently re-referred by their GP this will constitute a new RTT clock start.
20.12.8 New referral patients from other referring clinicians (eg consultant to consultant) will also be referred back to the original referrer.
20.12.9 E-referral patients who DNA follow the same pathway.
Non face to face appointments

An outpatient appointment is defined nationally as an appointment for a patient to see or have contact with a care professional at an outpatient clinic. Telephone and video consultations are considered to be Outpatient appointments and should be recorded as such on EPR.
20.13.1 Patients will be informed in advance of the date and time the clinican will contact them and contact numbers must be checked in advance to ensure accurate details for the patient.

20.13.2 Telephone and video appointments follow the same rules around templates, bookings, recording, outcomes, documentation etc as standard face to face appointments. For example if the patient fails to answer the telephone at the time of the appointment then this would be recorded as a DNA.
20.13.3 Any patient who declines a video consultation i.e does not own a smartphone or laptop, will be offered an alternative appointment type.
Attendance
On attending the outpatient clinic demographic details including current GP, address and updated contact telephone/mobile number must be checked with the patient by the clinic reception staff.
Attendance Outcome Coding

It is the responsibility of the clinical staff in the outpatient clinic to accurately report any procedures or treatment undertaken and identify the appropriate referral to treatment (RTT) outcome code on the outcome form.
Clinic staff must ensure that at the end of a clinic, all patients have a recorded outcome.
The receptionist must ensure that all information is accurately entered into EPR

The medical secretary will support the outpatient team in addressing missing RTT outcomes and procedures/treatments within 48 hours of the clinic date to enable all cashing up to be completed and updated on ESR.
OUTCOME forms

The clinic outcome is part of the patient's RTT pathway and as such the forms should be retained as part of the patient's medical records. They should be uploaded into the patients EMR especially for specialties who are noteless.
Diagnostics
Referrals for all diagnostic tests must be made via the electronic systems or by appropriate process set by each department.
Diagnostic tests do not stop the RTT clock.
Where possible, once patients have been referred for a diagnostic test after being seen in the outpatient clinic, they should be able to book their diagnostic appointment before leaving the hospital.
The National maximum waiting times for Diagnostic investigations are:
Cancer patients - 2 weeks;
Urgent patients - 4 weeks;
Routine request - 6 weeks.

The patient must be contacted by telephone to agree a date for their diagnostic test if a patient is not able to book their diagnostic test prior to leaving the hospital. Where the patient is not available on the first phone contact, a second attempt the following day at a different time is to take place.

Where the patient is still not available, an appointment contact letter (with date and time) will be sent to the patient within 24 hours for all urgent/cancer referrals, and 48 hours for routine, requesting them to ring the department if the appointment is not convenient.

When offering routine dates to patients for diagnostic tests, the locally agreed reasonable criteria of 2 weeks' notice must be given wherever possible with a choice of two dates. Should the patient refuse these dates, this must be recorded on all relevant systems.

Patients who cancel an offer of a diagnostic appointment date will be able to discuss another date for their procedure within their RTT pathway. ESR will be updated to reflect the cancelled appointment date. The diagnostic clock will be set to zero however their RTT clock continues.

Further dates should be offered to support patient choice and to accommodate the patient's diagnostic test being performed up to the 6 week point in the diagnostic pathway and 2 week rule for cancer patients.

The patient will be referred back to the referring clinician or GP (if direct access diagnostic,these patients are not on RTT pathways) if a further date cannot then be agreed within the target pathway.
Patients who have agreed their appointment date at short notice (i.e. less than 2 weeks), and then cancel - a further offer of a date will be made.

Where the patient has had a choice of date and time of the appointment but the patient does not attend the attendance will be recorded as a DNA and the requesting clinician will be informed with a view to the patient being referred back to the GP and discharged (RTT clock stops on clinical decision). NB this excludes cancer patients - see Cancer Access Policy.
For patients who DNA or cancel where the requesting clinician is the GP (Direct Access Services) the same rules apply as in section above.
Monitoring of the timeframes is the responsibility of the relevant Lead Manager for the diagnostic area.
Elective Inpatients and Day Cases
Pre-Operative Assessment
Pre-Operative Assessment will be undertaken for all patients requiring local or general anaesthesia where the procedure is carried out in an operating theatre.
23.1.1 A core pathway for pre-operative assessment has been agreed and implementation is tailored to each specialty.
23.1.2 For patients requiring day stay procedures the patient will complete a health questionnaire at the point of being added to the waiting list.

23.1.3 The pre assessment questionarie will be returned to the Pre Assessment team who will clinically review the information provided and arrange a Nurse-led or Consultant led Pre-Operative Assessment appointment is necessary. Not all day stay patients require pre operative assessment appointments.
23.1.4 For patients requiring overnight admission to hospital the Specialty Booking Clerk will contact the patient to agree a date for their pre operative assessment.
Booking Pre-Operative Assessment Appointments
Pre operative assessments will be booked in chronological and clinical urgency order.
23.2.1 The pre assessment must be within 4 months of the patients treatment date to ensure all clinical markers are not beyond recognised thresholds (MRSA status etc.).

23.2.2 The booking of patient's pre-operative assessment will be via discussion with the patient either in person or by telephone. Only if the patient cannot be verbally contacted then a letter with a date and time will be sent out.
23.2.3 In cases where an appointment letter is sent out the patient will be given 5 working days to respond and agree their appointment (a choice of 2 dates may be offered).

23.2.4 Where the patient fails to respond, the Service/General Manager should be informed. For urgent patients, discussion with the referring clinician must take place to ascertain if the patient should be referred back to the GP or a further date offered.
23.2.5 In cases where there is no response in relation to a child or Vulnerable Adult the relevant Safeguarding team must be notified.
23.2.6 Some patients may have pre-operative assessment via telephone, these must booked via the EPR system and letters generated via that system.
23.2.7 Outcomes of pre assessment appointments will be recorded as per any clinic appointment.
23.2.8 When a patient DNA's their agreed pre-assessment appointment date the patient should be contacted to ascertain the reason for the DNA. A further date will be agreed.
23.2.9 If a further DNA occurs, following discussion and agreement with the Clinician they will be discharged back to the care of their GP.
RTT Thinking time Decision

When a decision to treat is made at the Outpatient consultation, the patient may be given 5 working days thinking time to decide whether to proceed with treatment. In such cases it is the patient's responsibility to inform the Consultant's Medical Secretary that they wish to proceed. The outcome from clinic should include a comment that thinking time has been agreed. TheWeek clock will continue.
23.3.1  If the patient has decided not to proceed with the surgery the Consultant will be informed. If the patient is discharged the  Week pathway is stopped and the Consultant must write to the GP.
Decision to Admit
Patients may only be added to the elective waiting list under when they:
Are clinically ready (e.g. fit);
Have consent for treatment, and
Available to accept dates for treatment/surgery.
Adding patients to the Elective Waiting List

When the decision to admit (treat) has been made, a TCI form must be completed only by the clinician. The patient should be entered onto the appropriate ESR waiting list within 48 hours of the TCI form being written.
24.5.1 The clinician must include the clinical prioritisation as per the Royal College of Surgeons guidance and communicate this to the patient and GP.
24.5.2 Any incomplete TCI documents must be immediately returned to the clinician who has made the decision to admit/treat for clarity/correction.
24.5.3 When adding to the patient to the waiting list on ESR, the member of staff adding the patient must check the RTT status to ensure the patient's waiting time is calculated correctly.
Selecting a patient for admission from a Waiting List

Clinicians are responsible  for the  content of their admission waiting  lists. However, the responsibilities for allocating admission dates may be delegated to others including non-medically trained staff such as booking clerks and specialty managers. Allocation must be on the basis of clinical priority, “in turn” selection and pre-agreed case mix and in consultation with the clinician responsible for the theatre session.
23.6.1 It is also crucial that clinicians and other staff involved in the selection of patients for admission have access to up-to-date RTT waiting lists for appropriate ‘in turn' selection.
23.6.2 Clinicians must not place a patient on a waiting list to reserve a place against the possibility that treatment may be necessary in the future.

23.6.2 Where the patient is identified as unfit for the procedure, the nature and duration of the clinical issue should be ascertained. The RTT clock continues if the clinical issue is short term and has no impact on the original clinical decision to undertake the procedure (eg cough, cold, UTI).

23.6.3 However, if the nature of the clinical issue is more serious, for which the patient requires optimisation and/treatment, clinicians should indicate to the administration staff if it is clinically appropriate for the patient to be removed from the waiting list and, if so, whether the patient should be:
Optimised/treated within secondary care (active monitoring clock stop for existing pathway and potentially new clock start for optimisation treatment) or
Discharged back to the care of their GP (clock stop – discharge).
23.6.4 When the patient becomes fit and ready to be treated for the original condition, a new RTT clock would start on the day this decision is made and communicated to the patient.
23.6.5 Patients who are deemed unfit for surgery due to anaesthetic reasons should be referred by the clinician to the consultant Anaesthetist for review.
23.6.6 Written communication to the referring clinician with regards to the fitness of the patient for surgery will be provided post assessment.
23.6.7 The date of decision to admit will be when the patient is deemed fit for surgery at which point the patient can be added to the waiting list taking note of any specifics needed.
Long Waits
There is a zero tolerance of any patient waiting more than 52 weeks.

23.7.1  Any patient waiting over 40 weeks must be reported to the Director of Operations and discussed at the weekly RTT PTL meeting. In the event that a patient waits over  weeks this must be reported through the Trust's internal incident reporting process.
Bilateral Procedures
A bilateral procedure is a procedure that is performed on both sides of the body at matching anatomical sites, examples include:
Cataract removals and hip or knee replacements;
Consultant led bilateral procedures are covered by 18 weeks with a separate
clock for each procedure.
23.8.1 TheWeek clock for the first consultant led bilateral procedure will stop when the first procedure is carried out.
23.8.2 When the patient becomes fit and ready for the second consultant led bilateral procedure, a new 18 Week clock will start.
23.8.3 Patients requiring bilateral procedures should be added onto the waiting list one procedure at a time.
Adding Patients Seen Privately

Patients who have had a private outpatient appointment, but have elected to have NHS inpatient treatment with the same consultant, should be treated in the same way as patients who have had an NHS consultation eg they should be added to the list without delay from the date the referral is received from the private provider. This will be their RTT start date. Referrals received by medical secretaries should be registered on Medway and the usual grading and booking processes of the department followed.
Missed off the Waiting List

Where a patient contacts the Hospital to enquire about their operation and the Service Manager/Secretary notice that the patient is not on a waiting list the patient will be advised that the matter will escalated to the General Manager and a full investigation will start immediately.
23.10.1 The patient is then added to the Waiting List from the original clock start date.
23.10.2 The patient will be contacted by telephone and informed, and an explanation will be given.
23.10.3 Where a patient has been missed off the waiting list a Datix report is completed and the events will be recorded on the patient's contact log.
General Principles
Urgent patients and Cancer patients will be treated with priority, in date order and in turn. Urgent cases, as a rule, should be fully booked, because of the shorter waiting time for the patient.

23.11.1 Routine patients will be treated in turn based on their length of time on the 18 Week Pathway/Waiting list with case mix being taken into consideration. This is to ensure theatre time is fully utilised.

23.11.2 A patient may request to be treated by another Provider (subject to suitability and fitness etc.) if they are not treated within their 18 week pathway. When a patient requests for treatment elsewhere this must be escalated to the Associate Director – Elective Care.
Short Notice Arrangements (stand-by)

Admission slots that become available at short notice will be offered, in the first instance, to the next clinically urgent patient. It will be offered to appropriate routine patients who have been waiting the longest and are willing to accept short notice If the slot cannot be filled by a clinically urgent patient.
Reasonable Notice Period

Patients should be given choice in their procedure date and, therefore, full use of the available pathway time must be used. In accordance with the national guidance a ‘reasonable offer' of admission involves giving a patient the offer of 2 dates with at least 3 weeks' notice of their “TCI date (18 Week target).
Urgent patients may be offered one reasonable notice date;
If a patient accepts a unreasonable offer (less than 3 weeks' notice) this becomes a reasonable offer;
All dates offered are recorded on ESR;
Where a patient declines 2 reasonable offers, in agreement with clinician, the patient will be removed from the waiting list and referred back to the GP
Expedite Requests

The GP may also refer back to the clinician requesting the patient be reviewed urgently in the clinic for a further decision on the urgency to be made. Requests for expediting care should be addressed to:
Southend – Practices should go into the original referral via eRS and request
an earlier appointment for the paitent. This excludes MSK CATS as there is a specific email address to be used for this specialty MSK.expedite@southend.nhs.uk
Mid Essex – Practices should e-mail
MEHTOrthopaedicsSecretaries@meht.nhs.uk for Trauma and Orthopaedics and MEHTRheumatologySecretaries@meht.nhs.uk for Rheumatology requesting to expedite appointments
Basildon – Practices should send a letter to request expediting, or e-mail in to
Appointments.Centre@btuh.nhs.uk
Planned Waiting List

Patients who are added to the waiting list for a planned procedure are outside the scope of 18 weeks. Planned means an appointment/procedure or series of appointments/procedures as part of an agreed programme of care which is required for clinical reasons. This may entail treatment to be carried out at a specific time or repeated at a specific frequency.
23.15.1 Planned activity is also sometimes called “surveillance”, “re-do” or “check”.
23.15.2 Examples include 6 month repeat colonoscopy following removal of a malignancy, tumour or polyp.
23.15.3 Patients should only be included on planned waiting lists if there are clinical reasons why the patient cannot have the procedure or treatment until a specified time.
“Check” endoscopic procedures;
Removal of screws/metal work;
Age/growth related surgery;
Investigation/treatment sequences;
Awaiting transplants.

23.15.4 When adding patients to the elective planned waiting list, the Consultant specified timescale must be recorded under expected admission date (which in this case actually is a maximum waiting time) to ensure the patient is still selected in turn.

23.15.4 If the patient has not been treated within a month following the expected admission date the patient will be placed on an 18 Week pathway with a clock start commencing from their expected admission.
Booking Elective Admission
All elective patients will be fully or partially booked.
23.16.1 All patients are to be contacted by telephone at least  weeks' prior to their designated surgery/treatment time to book a date and time for their procedure.

23.16.2 Where the patient is not available on the first phone contact, a second attempt the following day at a different time is to take place. Should this attempt fails, a letter will be sent to the patient with their procedure date and time and the patient asked to call and confirm.
23.16.3 In the case of no contact with reference to Children or Vulnerable Adults the appropriate Safeguarding Team should be advised.
23.16.4 All booking should take place to enable the RTT pathway to be achieved.
23.16.5 Dates and times of calls as well as the dates and times offered for the procedure must be entered onto the ESR in real time to form part of an audit trail.
23.16.6 Where the patient fails to contact the hospital within 7 working days, the GP must be contacted to check patient contact details.
23.16.7 A ‘contact letter' will be sent to the patient asking them to respond within 14 days.

23.16.8 Where there is no response to the letter the referring clinician will be consulted and will inform whether the patient should be referred back to the GP and cancelled off the waiting list with the clock being stopped as this will be considered as patient declining treatment.
23.16.9 Where a patient declines the offer of the procedure or fails to contact the Trust every effort must be made to book the next in turn patient to ensure full utilisation of theatre capacity.
Outcomes of Admission Offers
Hospital Cancellations of Operation on the day
The hospital will only cancel a patient's admission on the day when it is not possible to carry out the procedure/treatment; for example:
Lack of available bed;
Unexpected absence of key staff;
Intake of emergency cases;
Patients deemed unfit for treatment/surgery.

24.1.1 When the patient's admission needs to be cancelled on the day the lead nurse for the specialty and the lead nurse for theatre will communicate with the Service Manager to inform them which patients have been cancelled and the reasons for cancellation. The 28 day rule will then apply.
24.1.2 If the patient has not yet been admitted the patient will be contacted by phone by either the booking clerk or the service manager.
24.1.3 When the patient's admission is cancelled on the day for non-clinical reasons this must be recorded as ‘Cancelled Elective Admission' on ESR and the theatre management system.
24.1.4 In the event that the hospital cancels a patients' admission date (TCI) the clock will continue.
24.1.5 There is a zero tolerance of urgent patients being cancelled more than once on the day of the operation and also a zero tolerance of routine patients being cancelled more than twice.
Hospital Cancellations of Operation before the day

Where the patient's admission needs to be put on standby/cancelled prior to the day of admission the Service Manager for the specialty will select potential patients suitable for cancellation and discuss these with the relevant Clinician. A risk assessment must be completed.
24.2.1 Where cancellations due to lack of beds are deemed necessary, priority will be given to clinically urgent cases, cancer cases, patients that are on a 28 day rule and 52 week waiters.
24.2.2 Any potential cancellation must be discussed with the Lead Manager for Theatres in the first instance and the Director for Operations will then be notified.
24.2.3 In the event of a cancellation going ahead the Lead Manager for Theatres, must liaise with relevant General Manager of the Specialty regarding the outcome.
24.2.4 Urgent patients cancelled before the day of admission will be given a new date at the earliest opportunity with the appropriate clinical priority.
24.2.5 Routine patients will be given a new date taking into account the relevant waiting time standard and the potential for breach.
24.2.6 In the event that the hospital cancels a patients' admission date (TCI) the clock will continue.
28 Day Rule
The 28 day rule is applicable unless the remainder of the 18 Week pathway is shorter.

24.3.1 All patients that are cancelled on the day of admission for non-clinical reasons must be offered a date within 28 days of their cancellation. Breaches of the 28 day standard are reported nationally. All patients will be escalated to the Lead Clinician for assessment and resolution. The Trust should investigate the causes and implement actions to address them.
24.3.2 Where the patient is offered a date within the 28 days, but declines the date they will be offered the next available date that the patient is available, which may exceed the 28 days.

24.3.3 Where it is not possible to offer the patient a new date within 28 days for example; if the surgeon is on annual leave, the patient may be offered an alternative surgeon and/or a suitable alternative provider (subject to suitability and fitness etc.). These arrangements require patient consent to proceed.
Patient Cancellations

Patients who cancel an offer of an admission date with a valid reason will be able to discuss another date for their procedure within their RTT pathway. ESR must be updated to reflect the cancelled admission date and record the reason why.
Did not attend (DNA's)

When a patient DNA's their agreed pre-assessment appointment date or their elective admission (TCI) date, the patient should be contacted to ascertain the reason for the DNA. A further date will be agreed.
24.5.1 If a further DNA occurs, following discussion with the Clinician the patient may be discharged back to the care of their GP for review and re-assessment.

24.1.2 When a patient DNAs their pre-assessment date and a TCI date was booked, the TCI will be cancelled from ESR and Theatre system by the relevant booking clerk. The patient will be contacted to agree a further pre assessment date.

24.1.3 When the patient is referred back to the GP, a letter must be sent to the GP and the patient notifying them of their removal from the elective waiting list and the clock stopped by the administrative team. The patient may be re-referred at the discretion of the GP.
Cancelling for Clinical Reasons
When a patient is cancelled as medically unfit and is likely to be fit within the following 2 week period the RTT clock continiues and a new procedure date agreed when the patient is fit.
24.6.1 It is the patient's responsibility to contact the Consultant Secretary when they are fit, providing this is within an 8 week period.
24.6.2 A decision will be made by the clinician whether the patient can be re-added to the waiting list without attending a further pre-assessment appointment. This will be a new clock start.
24.6.3 Where the patient is cancelled as medically unfit and this is expected to be for more than 8 weeks the patient will be discharged back to the care of the GP by the clinician.
Patients Who Move Out Of the Area
When a patient moves from the area covered by the hospital they may wish to transfer their treatment to a provider closer to their new home.
24.7.1 Should the patient choose to remain on the Trust's waiting list there is no change in status and the RTT clock continues to tick.
24.7.2 Patients choosing to transfer their care to a new Trust as a result of their move out of our area will be discharged to the care of their GP. This will result in a clock stop.
Transfer of Treatment to another Consultant

Occasionally it may be necessary to transfer a patient's treatment to another Consultant (eg Consultant sickness/no longer at the Trust/capacity). In such circumstances the Trust should seek permission from the patient to transfer their care to another named Consultant team. When the patient is in agreement, waiting times are unaffected and ESR must be updated. Where necessary, an outpatient appointment is made within one month which must be clearly documented in the case notes and on ESR. Under the above circumstances the RTT pathway remains on-going. Should the patient choose to decline this offer and no other Consultant team are able to perform the procedure, the patient should be informed and referred back to their GP and removed from the waiting list. This will result in a clock stop.
Transfer between Waiting Lists within the Trust

This may be appropriate where the patient has been added to a waiting list for a specific procedure and it is subsequently possible to treat the patient sooner or more effectively in an alternative manner (eg as day case instead of an inpatient).
25.1.1 The patient has the right to refuse the transfer if the transfer will result in treatment by a different Consultant.
25.1.2 The patient's status on the waiting list will not be affected should they refuse to be transferred to the care of a different Consultant.
Transfer to another NHS Provider/Private or Independent Hospital
Patients may be transferred from the waiting list of one provider to another provider for their treatment. The transfer must always be with the consent of the patient and provider.
25.2.1 Patients transferred on an 18 week RTT to another provider must have a comprehensive referral including a minimum data set (MDS) sent to the accepting consultant/trust.
25.2.2 The MDS should be logged centrally.
25.2.3 The RTT status of the patient transfers to the new provider unless this is explicitely agreed by both organisations.
Training Requirements
A training needs analysis has been undertaken and used to inform the level of training required for each staff group.

An e-learning package is available for all staff outlining the care of patients on RTT pathways and face to face sessions as required. All staff will be expected to achieve a ‘ESRs' with the on line tests attached to the training package.
Staff Competencies and Compliance
Competency
As a key part of their induction programme, all new starters to the trust will undergo mandatory contextual elective care training applicable to their role.
27.1.1 All existing staff will undergo mandatory contextual elective care training on at least an annual basis.
27.1.2 All staff will carry out competency tests that are clearly documented to provide evidence that they have the required level of knowledge and ability.
27.1.3 This policy, along with the supporting suite of SOPs, will form the basis of contextual training programmes (refer to the elective care training strategy for more information).
Compliance
Functional teams, specialties and staff will be performance managed against key performance indicators (KPIs) applicable to their role.
27.2.1 Role specific KPIs are based on the principles in this policy and specific aspects of the trust's standard operating procedures.

27.2.2 In the event of non-compliance, a resolution should initially be sought by the team, specialty or individual's line manager. The matter should then be dealt with via the trust's disciplinary or capability procedure.
Monitoring of compliance

Compliance to this policy will be reviewed through audit of patient pathways. This audit will occur at least annually, where at least 50 patient pathways will be reviewed and validated to ensure consistency of policy application.
The overarching patient access metrics (such as 18 week standard compliance and performance) will be formally reviewed and challenged as follows:
MSE Access Board;
Monthly Performance Review meetings with the Executive board;
Trust Board;
Elective Performance meetings - operational staff.
Equality Impact Assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and
meets the needs of all individuals. (Refer to Appendix 2)
